\begin{center}
Welcome tom my project webpage. You will find here a list of ongoing or past projects I have worked on.
\end{center}

- [Article Review of The carbon footprint of capital, by Chancel and Rehm in 2024](https://www.paulogcd.com/TPEE_Presentation/) : This is a group presentation done during the fall semester of 2024-2025 for the class “Topics in Public and Environmental Economics” taught by [Stefan Pollinger](https://www.stefanpollinger.com/). We were asked to present in one hour the working paper of Chancel and Rehm about how to account the Carbon Footprint of Capital. The link sends you to a dedicated section on Paulo's website with our slides and a detailed summary of the article. The latest version of the article is available [here](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fi/8jsi7pgno80xlhhjsu3zc/CarbonCapital2023ChancelRehm.pdf?rlkey=nu70bve6k1ofmqz2zpttox9gh&e=1).

- [Macroeconomics Group Presentation about the Diamond Dybvig model of Bank Runs](macro_pre.pdf) : 
This is a group presentation done in the spring semester of 2024 for the "Macroeconomics 2" class taught by [Jean Barthélemy](https://sites.google.com/site/jeanbarthelemyeconomist/home) (Banque de France) that consisted in a one hour presentation of the paper ["Bank runs, Deposit Insurance, and Liquidity"](https://www.jstor.org/stable/1837095), by Douglas W. Diamond and Philip H. Dybvig (2020). We received the grade of 19/20 for this presentation.

- [Microeconomics Group project about modelling class attendance in a Game Theoretical Framework](Micro_Group_Project.pdf) : 
This is a group project done in the spring semester of 2024 for the "Microeconomics 2" class taught by [Emeric Henry](https://sites.google.com/site/emericmlhenry/home) (Sciences Po Paris) that consisted in elaborating a game using notions seen in class. We choose to do it on strategic interactions between students in a context of class attendance. We received the grade of 17.5/20 for this work.

- [Political Economy Theory Paper: "Who controls the flows? A comparative analysis of Fernand Braudel and David Harvey"](theory-paper_braudel-harvey.pdf) : 
This is a theory paper done in the fall semester of 2022 for the POLECON 101 class (Contemporary Theory of Political Economy) taught by [Steven K. Vogel](https://polisci.berkeley.edu/people/person/steven-vogel) (UC Berkeley) that consisted in connecting a reading from an author studied in lecture to an author from our personal references. This work received the grade of A+.
